Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\) with \\( \omega \\) a real constant. We examine the effect of a Fourier transform \\( F(s) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-2\pi ist}z(t) \, dt \\) on this function over the variable s.

If an operation alters \\( z(t) \\) such that \\( z(t) = a \cdot e^{i \omega t} \\) with a constant scalar a before applying the Fourier transform, will the position of the peak in \\( F(s) \\) change?
Explanation: The operation of scaling \\( z(t) \\) by a constant scalar \\( a \\) affects the amplitude but not the frequency of the function. Thus, the Fourier transform \\( F(s) \\) will still peak at \\( s = \omega / (2\pi) \\). This demonstrates that scaling the input merely affects amplitude and does not displace the frequency components in the Fourier transform domain.
